channel.title: Where can I find the cheapest
channel.description:
Where can I find the cheapest servers to run some stuff on?
I actually want to buy a vps or dedicated server and set it up in my house so I can run some stuff on it.
Where should I go to get the cheapest one's because I don't want to get ripped.

item.title: Where can I find the cheapest
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:20, topic:439853”]PS: A home connection won’t cut it for anything useful.[/quote]That’s what I was saying

Read full topic
item.source: Where can I find the cheapest

item.title: Where can I find the cheapest
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

PS: A home connection won’t cut it for anything useful.

Read full topic
item.source: Where can I find the cheapest

item.title: Where can I find the cheapest
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:18, topic:439853”][quote author=Kidpaparoach link=topic=542543.msg3977040#msg3977040 date=1334776605]

there’s really no difference between a desktop and server as far as hardware goes…

Fans for a start, how the hardware is put together as VPS’s are much easier to remove and put parts into and more but I’m no expert in the matter but there is a difference. VPS’s are meant to act as main server(s)/host(w.e.), desktops are not meant for this as we all know.[quote author=jmood128 link=topic=542543.msg3976447#msg3976447 date=1334704555]
My desktop hasn’t turned off since I bought it back in December, well the only time it’s been off is for updating and power outages which isn’t much…

Though you could still build a good vps, or even if you wanted you could buy a few low cost computers and turn it into a cloud.

One reason why you might want to turn it off is economic. A typical PC consumes something like 300 watts. Let’s assume that you use your PC for four hours every day, so the other 20 hours it is on would be wasted energy. If electricity costs 10 cents per kilowatt-hour in your area, then that 20 hours represents 60 cents a day. Sixty cents a day adds up to $219 per year.

why in the living fuck would you want a full blown server rack if you’re not on a line equivalent to that of a datacentre, or even the same power grid?

Hmmmm? I think you misunderstand, a VPS not multiple vps’s on a rack? I honestly don’t know what your on about…

VPS = virtual private server. This means that a VPS is a virtualized OS sitting on a host box which is usually pretty hefty. The reason why people sell them is because they don’t have to keep buying hardware for each client.

This being said, why would you even consider buying a box just to have a virtual OS on it when you own the entire box. Further more, what’s the point buying legit server hardware when you’re on a domestic internet connection and power grid?

I know what a VPS is… if that wasn’t obvious. Its not unless you buy it brand new then its typically the same price as a desktop.
Eh? Why are you over complicating this? I don’t even get what your trying to get at…
I think your trying to say why aren’t you using it to its full capacity??? In response to that vps’s second hand are cheap, cheaper than second hand desktops a lot of the time, thats why.

you don’t buy physical VPS’s… they’re not physical items whether you’re building a machine to run virtual guests or renting a virtual guest from a hosting company… VPS’s are headless virtual machines.
[/quote]
Ah I get what your meaning now, I portray what I’m thinking badly a lot of the time. I meant buy a server basically, not use a desktop for a servers job>.>. I just call them vps’s because when I browse ebay I usually find them named under vps’s…
[/quote]
i’m going to disregard the last part of your reply because i’m not going down that road.

here’s a really cool thing: server hardware and desktop hardware has no difference, especially on the scale you’ll be using the machine for. i don’t really understand your gripe at using a desktop machine as a server (yeah a desktop OS may not be the best of choices, but the hardware is).[/quote]
Yes, I know that… I meant how its been made as I previously said, sigh. I explain things badly and I can’t be bothered trying to explain it, your thinking I’m saying something I’m not :L

Read full topic
item.source: Where can I find the cheapest

item.title: Where can I find the cheapest
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Kidpaparoach, post:17, topic:439853”][quote author=t4 link=topic=542543.msg3977034#msg3977034 date=1334776385]

there’s really no difference between a desktop and server as far as hardware goes…

Fans for a start, how the hardware is put together as VPS’s are much easier to remove and put parts into and more but I’m no expert in the matter but there is a difference. VPS’s are meant to act as main server(s)/host(w.e.), desktops are not meant for this as we all know.[quote author=jmood128 link=topic=542543.msg3976447#msg3976447 date=1334704555]
My desktop hasn’t turned off since I bought it back in December, well the only time it’s been off is for updating and power outages which isn’t much…

Though you could still build a good vps, or even if you wanted you could buy a few low cost computers and turn it into a cloud.

One reason why you might want to turn it off is economic. A typical PC consumes something like 300 watts. Let’s assume that you use your PC for four hours every day, so the other 20 hours it is on would be wasted energy. If electricity costs 10 cents per kilowatt-hour in your area, then that 20 hours represents 60 cents a day. Sixty cents a day adds up to $219 per year.

why in the living fuck would you want a full blown server rack if you’re not on a line equivalent to that of a datacentre, or even the same power grid?

Hmmmm? I think you misunderstand, a VPS not multiple vps’s on a rack? I honestly don’t know what your on about…

VPS = virtual private server. This means that a VPS is a virtualized OS sitting on a host box which is usually pretty hefty. The reason why people sell them is because they don’t have to keep buying hardware for each client.

This being said, why would you even consider buying a box just to have a virtual OS on it when you own the entire box. Further more, what’s the point buying legit server hardware when you’re on a domestic internet connection and power grid?

I know what a VPS is… if that wasn’t obvious. Its not unless you buy it brand new then its typically the same price as a desktop.
Eh? Why are you over complicating this? I don’t even get what your trying to get at…
I think your trying to say why aren’t you using it to its full capacity??? In response to that vps’s second hand are cheap, cheaper than second hand desktops a lot of the time, thats why.
[/quote]
you don’t buy physical VPS’s… they’re not physical items whether you’re building a machine to run virtual guests or renting a virtual guest from a hosting company… VPS’s are headless virtual machines.
[/quote]
Ah I get what your meaning now, I portray what I’m thinking badly a lot of the time. I meant buy a server basically, not use a desktop for a servers job>.>. I just call them vps’s because when I browse ebay I usually find them named under vps’s…[/quote]
i’m going to disregard the last part of your reply because i’m not going down that road.

here’s a really cool thing: server hardware and desktop hardware has no difference, especially on the scale you’ll be using the machine for. i don’t really understand your gripe at using a desktop machine as a server (yeah a desktop OS may not be the best of choices, but the hardware is).

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Kidpaparoach, post:13, topic:439853”][quote author=t4 link=topic=542543.msg3977010#msg3977010 date=1334774523]

there’s really no difference between a desktop and server as far as hardware goes…

Fans for a start, how the hardware is put together as VPS’s are much easier to remove and put parts into and more but I’m no expert in the matter but there is a difference. VPS’s are meant to act as main server(s)/host(w.e.), desktops are not meant for this as we all know.[quote author=jmood128 link=topic=542543.msg3976447#msg3976447 date=1334704555]
My desktop hasn’t turned off since I bought it back in December, well the only time it’s been off is for updating and power outages which isn’t much…

Though you could still build a good vps, or even if you wanted you could buy a few low cost computers and turn it into a cloud.

One reason why you might want to turn it off is economic. A typical PC consumes something like 300 watts. Let’s assume that you use your PC for four hours every day, so the other 20 hours it is on would be wasted energy. If electricity costs 10 cents per kilowatt-hour in your area, then that 20 hours represents 60 cents a day. Sixty cents a day adds up to $219 per year.

[/quote]
why in the living fuck would you want a full blown server rack if you’re not on a line equivalent to that of a datacentre, or even the same power grid?
[/quote]
Hmmmm? I think you misunderstand, a VPS not multiple vps’s on a rack? I honestly don’t know what your on about…[/quote]
VPS = virtual private server. This means that a VPS is a virtualized OS sitting on a host box which is usually pretty hefty. The reason why people sell them is because they don’t have to keep buying hardware for each client.

This being said, why would you even consider buying a box just to have a virtual OS on it when you own the entire box. Further more, what’s the point buying legit server hardware when you’re on a domestic internet connection and power grid?

item.title: Where can I find the cheapest
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

marcbob:

Probably is a better idea to just buy a desktop and use it.

You can get desktops dirt cheap second hand etc. Some people give them away for free like I have a computer sitting in my room which is completely outdated but still has half decent specs.
I’d just buy a second hand vps of ebay as there cheap and there aimed at hosting, consideration is taken into how a vps is made as when its made they know its going to be on near enough 24/7.
Computers aren’t meant for that although mines at least can handle being on for 3 weeks(not left it on for longer) pretty well(even though its got a amd athlon processor)

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

marcbob:

I actually want to buy a vps or dedicated server and set it up in my house so I can run some stuff on it.

wat

[quote=“marcbob, post:3, topic:439853”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=542543.msg3975657#msg3975657 date=1334622906]

[quote author=marcbob link=topic=542543.msg3975649#msg3975649 date=1334622402]in my house
[/quote]Bad idea.
[/quote]

Why so? Not looking to run anything important on them. I don’t want to run a whole datacenter at my house I just want like 1 server.[/quote]
just build a comp with good enough specs for what you intend to serve on it. DMZ it and run it 24/7 and you’re done.

Read full topic

item.title: Where can I find the cheapest
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:

[quote author=marcbob link=topic=542543.msg3975649#msg3975649 date=1334622402]in my house
[/quote]Bad idea.
[/quote]

Why so? Not looking to run anything important on them. I don’t want to run a whole datacenter at my house I just want like 1 server.[/quote]Just internal stuff? Then I guess it’d be ok. But if you run a RSPS or anything external I’d say it’s a bad idea, because if someone tries to hit your server offline for whatever reason, you’d be hit offline completely.
